question: Which of the following is not a bowel disease virus (enterovirus) caused?
prompt:
Which of the following is not a bowel disease virus (enterovirus) caused?A)Hand-foot-mouth disease
B)Herpangina
C)Pharyngoconjunctival fever
D)Aseptic meningitis
output0: Hand-foot-mouth disease is caused by a different type of virus, called an enterovirus. The other three options (Herpangina, Pharyngoconjunctival fever, and Aseptic meningitis) are all caused by enteroviruses.
output1: Herpangina is not caused by an enterovirus, but rather by the coxsackievirus.
output2: Pharyngoconjunctival fever is a viral infection that affects the throat and eyes, but it is not caused by an enterovirus. The other options (hand-foot-mouth disease, herpangina, and aseptic meningitis) are all caused by enteroviruses.
output3: Aseptic meningitis is not caused by an enterovirus, but rather by a bacterial or fungal infection. Enteroviruses are responsible for the other three options: hand-foot-mouth disease, herpangina, and pharyngoconjunctival fever.

question: Initiation of pulpal sensation by stimulating dentin is mediated by?
prompt:
Initiation of pulpal sensation by stimulating dentin is mediated by?A)A-delta myelinated fibers
B)A-beta myelinated fibers
C)Unmyelinated C fibers
D)Myelinated C fibers
output0: A-delta myelinated fibers are responsible for transmitting sensory information from the pulp to the dentinal tubules. These fibers are sensitive to pressure and temperature changes, and are the main fibers responsible for initiating pulpal sensation.
output1: A-beta myelinated fibers are responsible for the transmission of sensory information from the pulp to the dentinal tubules and the dentin-pulp complex. These fibers are specifically responsible for the initiation of pulpal sensation by stimulating the dentin.
output2: The unmyelinated C fibers are responsible for transmitting pain sensations from the dentin to the brain. These fibers are more sensitive to pressure and temperature changes, and they are more likely to be activated during dental procedures.
output3: Myelinated C fibers are responsible for transmitting sensory information from the dentin to the pulp. They are the main fibers that mediate the sensation of pain from the dentin to the brain.

question: An 80-year-old man is taken to the emergency room by the police when he finds him at night, in the street, several blocks from his home, something lost. He tells the emergency doctor "I feel fine, I was walking and I got lost". The review by systems, is anodyne. When asked about medications, he does not remember. His record includes glipizide, atenolol and acenocoumarol. He has been 3 times in the emergency department in the last 3 months due to "dizziness", back pain and an INR of 5.0. It refers independence in the basic and instrumental activities of daily life. There is no evidence of relatives or close friends. Several references of social work in the area indicate that it refuses aid or medical or nursing visits. In the physical examination, only highlights temperature of 37.7ºC, BMI of 16 Kg / m2, PA 160/90 mmHg, heart rate 90 bpm and oxygen saturation of 99%. It has a global loss of muscle mass. He is dressed in his housecoat and smells of urine. Refuses to answer the Mini-Mental questions. The laboratory tests include 13,000 leukocytes / microL, blood glucose 300 mg / dL, hemoglobin A1c 11%, INR 0.9. Urine: more than 50 leukocytes / field and nitrites +. Uroculture:> 100,000 colonies of gram-negative bacilli. He is admitted to the hospital, receives antibiotics, insulin and re-starts acenocoumarol with good evolution. He is stable and wants to go to his home. The plant nurse reports that she is unable to self-administer insulin. Which of the following is the next step in determining patient safety at your home?
correct_answer: Formal evaluation of the ability to make decisions concerning your health.
options: A)Refer to Primary Care and social work in the area to determine home security.
B)Formal evaluation of the ability to make decisions concerning your health.
prompt:
An 80-year-old man is taken to the emergency room by the police when he finds him at night, in the street, several blocks from his home, something lost. He tells the emergency doctor "I feel fine, I was walking and I got lost". The review by systems, is anodyne. When asked about medications, he does not remember. His record includes glipizide, atenolol and acenocoumarol. He has been 3 times in the emergency department in the last 3 months due to "dizziness", back pain and an INR of 5.0. It refers independence in the basic and instrumental activities of daily life. There is no evidence of relatives or close friends. Several references of social work in the area indicate that it refuses aid or medical or nursing visits. In the physical examination, only highlights temperature of 37.7ºC, BMI of 16 Kg / m2, PA 160/90 mmHg, heart rate 90 bpm and oxygen saturation of 99%. It has a global loss of muscle mass. He is dressed in his housecoat and smells of urine. Refuses to answer the Mini-Mental questions. The laboratory tests include 13,000 leukocytes / microL, blood glucose 300 mg / dL, hemoglobin A1c 11%, INR 0.9. Urine: more than 50 leukocytes / field and nitrites +. Uroculture:> 100,000 colonies of gram-negative bacilli. He is admitted to the hospital, receives antibiotics, insulin and re-starts acenocoumarol with good evolution. He is stable and wants to go to his home. The plant nurse reports that she is unable to self-administer insulin. Which of the following is the next step in determining patient safety at your home?A)Refer to Primary Care and social work in the area to determine home security.
B)Formal evaluation of the ability to make decisions concerning your health.
C)Evaluation to rule out dementia.
D)Evaluation to rule out depression.
output0: The correct answer is A)Refer to Primary Care and social work in the area to determine home security. This is the next step in determining patient safety at home, as the patient has been found to be lost and has a history of recent hospitalizations and medication use. It is important to assess the patient's ability to safely navigate their home environment and to identify any potential safety risks or hazards.
output1: The patient has been admitted to the hospital multiple times in the past 3 months, has a history of refusing medical or nursing visits, and is unable to self-administer insulin. These are all signs of potential decision-making impairment. Therefore, a formal evaluation of the patient's ability to make decisions concerning their health is necessary to ensure their safety at home.
output2: The patient's history of recent hospitalizations, confusion, and inability to self-administer insulin suggest a possible dementia or cognitive impairment. Therefore, it is important to evaluate the patient's cognitive status to determine if there is a need for further interventions or support.
output3: The patient's history of multiple emergency department visits for "dizziness", back pain, and an INR of 5.0, along with their recent refusal of medical or nursing visits, suggests that they may be experiencing depression or anxiety. Additionally, the patient's global loss of muscle mass, smell of urine, and refusal to answer the Mini-Mental questions indicate that they may be experiencing cognitive impairment or dementia. Therefore, the next step in determining patient safety at home is to evaluate the patient for depression and cognitive impairment.

question: Which of the following hormone crosses the plasma membrane for its action?
prompt:
Which of the following hormone crosses the plasma membrane for its action?A)Epinephrine
B)Glucagon
C)Insulin
D)Thyroxine
output0: Epinephrine is a hormone that crosses the plasma membrane for its action. It is produced by the adrenal glands and plays a key role in the body's "fight or flight" response. It causes an increase in heart rate, blood pressure, and energy levels.
output1: Glucagon is a hormone that crosses the plasma membrane to increase blood glucose levels by stimulating the liver to release glucose into the bloodstream.
output2: Insulin is a hormone that crosses the plasma membrane to act on cells in the body. It is produced by the pancreas and helps regulate blood sugar levels by facilitating the uptake of glucose by cells.
output3: Thyroxine is a hormone that is secreted by the thyroid gland and crosses the plasma membrane to affect target cells. The other hormones listed (epinephrine, glucagon, and insulin) are all produced by endocrine glands and do not cross the plasma membrane.

question: A 24-year-old woman presents to a physician with recurrent episodes of palpitations, shortness of breath, and perspiration. The episodes are self-limited and are usually preceded by specific social circumstances that she does not enjoy. There is no significant past medical history. After a complete history and physical examination, the physician diagnoses an anxiety disorder. He explains that anxiety is associated with the stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system which produces several symptoms related to anxiety such as tachycardia. Which of the following cellular mechanisms best explains the effects of stimulation of sympathetic cardiac nerves on the pacemaker cells in the sinoatrial node?
correct_answer: Facilitation of If currents through HCN channels
options: A)Decreased intracellular cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) level in the sinoatrial node
B)Inactivation of L-type voltage-gated calcium channels
C)Facilitation of If currents through HCN channels
D)Opening of G-protein activated potassium channels
prompt:
A 24-year-old woman presents to a physician with recurrent episodes of palpitations, shortness of breath, and perspiration. The episodes are self-limited and are usually preceded by specific social circumstances that she does not enjoy. There is no significant past medical history. After a complete history and physical examination, the physician diagnoses an anxiety disorder. He explains that anxiety is associated with the stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system which produces several symptoms related to anxiety such as tachycardia. Which of the following cellular mechanisms best explains the effects of stimulation of sympathetic cardiac nerves on the pacemaker cells in the sinoatrial node?A)Decreased intracellular cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) level in the sinoatrial node
B)Inactivation of L-type voltage-gated calcium channels
C)Facilitation of If currents through HCN channels
D)Opening of G-protein activated potassium channels
output0: The stimulation of sympathetic cardiac nerves produces an increase in catecholamines such as norepinephrine, which in turn decreases the intracellular cAMP level in the sinoatrial node. This decrease in cAMP levels inhibits the pacemaker activity of the sinoatrial node and increases the heart rate.
output1: The correct answer is B)Inactivation of L-type voltage-gated calcium channels. When the sympathetic nervous system is stimulated, it can inhibit the pacemaker cells in the sinoatrial node by decreasing the intracellular calcium levels, which is necessary for the pacemaker cells to function properly. This is because the L-type calcium channels are responsible for the influx of calcium ions into the cell, and when these channels are inactivated, the pacemaker cells are unable to generate the necessary electrical impulses to regulate the heartbeat.
output2: The correct answer is C)Facilitation of If currents through HCN channels. The sympathetic nervous system stimulation leads to an increase in intracellular cAMP levels, which in turn increases the activity of protein kinase A (PKA). This increases the activity of the hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channels, leading to the facilitation of If currents and an increase in the pacemaker activity.
output3: The opening of G-protein activated potassium channels is the cellular mechanism that best explains the effects of stimulation of sympathetic cardiac nerves on the pacemaker cells in the sinoatrial node. When sympathetic nerves are stimulated, it activates G-proteins, which in turn open potassium channels, leading to a decrease in the pacemaker cell's membrane potential and an increase in the heart rate.

question: Which pa of scaphoid fracture is most susceptible to avascular necrosis?
prompt:
Which pa of scaphoid fracture is most susceptible to avascular necrosis?A)Distal 1/3rd
B)Middle 1/3rd
C)Proximal 1/3rd
D)Scaphoid Tubercle
output0: The distal 1/3rd of the scaphoid bone is most susceptible to avascular necrosis due to its location and blood supply. This area is farthest from the main blood vessels, making it more prone to ischemia and necrosis.
output1: The middle 1/3rd of the scaphoid bone is most susceptible to avascular necrosis due to its anatomical location and blood supply. This area is prone to ischemia due to the limited blood supply, which can lead to avascular necrosis.
output2: The proximal one-third of the scaphoid bone is most susceptible to avascular necrosis due to its anatomical location and the risk of injury to the blood vessels that supply it.
output3: The scaphoid tubercle is the most susceptible to avascular necrosis due to its anatomical location and blood supply. It is located in the distal pole of the scaphoid bone, which is the most distant part of the bone from the proximal pole, and therefore, it receives less blood supply. Additionally, the tubercle is surrounded by a thin layer of cartilage, which can hinder the healing process.

question: Omalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody used for the treatment of:
prompt:
Omalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody used for the treatment of:A)Severe allergic asthma.
B)Chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
C)Metastatic colorectal cancer.
D)Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.
output0: Omalizumab is a medication used to treat severe allergic asthma. It works by blocking the action of immunoglobulin E (IgE), a protein that causes allergic reactions. By blocking the action of IgE, omalizumab can help reduce the symptoms of allergic asthma, such as wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath.
output1: Omalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that works by inhibiting the activity of immunoglobulin E (IgE), a protein that plays a central role in allergic reactions. It is used to treat severe allergic asthma, but not chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL is a type of cancer that develops in the blood and bone marrow.
output2: Omalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that is used to treat metastatic colorectal cancer. It works by blocking the activity of a protein called interleukin-6 (IL-6), which is involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells.
output3: Omalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that works by blocking the activity of a protein called CD52, which is found on the surface of red blood cells. This protein is involved in the immune system's attack on red blood cells in patients with Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). By blocking the activity of CD52, omalizumab helps to prevent the immune system from attacking red blood cells, which can help to reduce the symptoms of PNH.

question: No spore-forming anaerobic (non-sporeforming anaerobes) infect humans, the most common form of the disease that caused the following?
prompt:
No spore-forming anaerobic (non-sporeforming anaerobes) infect humans, the most common form of the disease that caused the following?A)Food poisoning (food poisoning)
B)Hemolytic anemia (hemolytic anemia)
C)Tissue necrosis and abscess (abscess)
D)Autoimmune disease (autoimmune diseases)
output0: Non-sporeforming anaerobes are not known to infect humans. The correct answer is A)Food poisoning (food poisoning), which is the most common form of the disease caused by spore-forming anaerobes.
output1: Non-sporeforming anaerobes are a type of bacteria that can cause hemolytic anemia, a condition where the red blood cells are destroyed. This can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
output2: Non-sporeforming anaerobes are a type of bacteria that can cause tissue necrosis and abscesses. They are not typically associated with food poisoning, hemolytic anemia, or autoimmune diseases.
output3: Non-sporeforming anaerobes are not known to cause human infections. The correct answer is D)Autoimmune disease (autoimmune diseases), as this is the most common form of the disease that can cause the symptoms described.

question: As in the case of the B lymphocyte receptor, the antigenic receptor of the T lymphocytes:
correct_answer: Consists of C domains and V domains
options: C)It is produced in secreted form.
D)Consists of C domains and V domains
prompt:
As in the case of the B lymphocyte receptor, the antigenic receptor of the T lymphocytes:A)Experience isotypic change.
B)Experience somatic hypermutation.
C)It is produced in secreted form.
D)Consists of C domains and V domains
output0: The B lymphocyte receptor, like the T lymphocyte receptor, undergoes a process called isotypic change, where the receptor is modified to better fit the antigen it is recognizing. This process is necessary for the proper functioning of the immune system.
output1: Just like the B lymphocyte receptor, the Turtle Technique involves the process of somatic hypermutation, which is the ability of the immune system to generate a wide variety of antibodies through the process of somatic mutation. This process allows the immune system to adapt and respond to new antigens more effectively.
output2: The B lymphocyte receptor is a transmembrane protein that is produced in secreted form, unlike the T lymphocyte receptor, which is produced intracellularly and then transported to the cell surface.
output3: The B lymphocyte receptor, like the T lymphocyte receptor, is a type of antigen receptor that is produced by T cells. It is composed of C domains and V domains, which are responsible for binding to specific antigens and triggering an immune response.

question: The prevalence figures of depressive problems:
correct_answer: They are greater in women than in men.
options: A)They have decreased in the last decades.
B)They are greater in the rural area than in the urban one.
C)They are greater in women than in men.
D)They do not show differences according to sex.
prompt:
The prevalence figures of depressive problems:A)They have decreased in the last decades.
B)They are greater in the rural area than in the urban one.
C)They are greater in women than in men.
D)They do not show differences according to sex.
output0: The prevalence of depressive problems has decreased in the last decades due to the improvement of mental health care and the implementation of prevention programs.
output1: The prevalence of depressive problems is higher in rural areas than in urban areas. This may be due to the fact that rural areas often have less access to mental health resources and services, as well as a greater risk of social isolation.
output2: According to various studies, depressive problems are more common in women than in men, and this is especially true during adolescence. This may be due to the fact that girls and women are more likely to experience gender-based discrimination and other forms of oppression, which can lead to increased feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and helplessness.
output3: Depressive problems are not more prevalent in one sex than the other. Depression can affect anyone, regardless of gender.
